Key Arguments: The legislation is not justified by sufficient evidence of harm from misinformation and disinformation.
Existing laws and regulations are adequate to address misinformation without new legislation.
The definitions of misinformation and disinformation are circular and biased towards official positions.
The legislation could infringe on freedom of political expression and due process.
The bill could lead to platforms over-censoring content to avoid penalties, stifling free speech.
Fact-checkers are not independent and may have conflicts of interest.
The legislation favors legacy media and imposes barriers to entry for new media platforms.
The bill could have negative economic and scientific impacts by stifling innovation and open discourse.
Main Themes: Impact on Innovation and Scientific Inquiry
Notable Quotes: The ASF has concerns about the proposed amendments to the act and believes it would be against the interests of scientific advancement and democracy for it to be passed.
The bill relies on a circular definition of misinformation and disinformation, whereby the official position is the ‘true’ one, and contradictory information is ‘misinformation or disinformation.’
Platforms will be incentivised to ‘play it safe’... This means that digital platforms will remove or restrict content that counters official positions.
Fact Checkers are engaged by digital platforms as independent arbiters of truth. However, they are not independent, and they have no greater claim to truth than anyone else.
